Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery lekythos; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of two women sharing a mantle; only right hand woman, looking to left, with right hand raised, remains (added red eye-dot, red curls over forehead, red head-band, necklace, decorated bands on peplos at neckline and waist), with part of the big mantle (wide red band at top with added white dots above and below, between white lines; red disks surrounded by white dots); above the mantle, seemingly standing on it, a bird, vulture or swan (red wing band with white dots above; white band on tail); on right, trace of side-border.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Haspels, C. H. E., Attic Black Figured Lekythoi. Paris 1936, 26, attributes this sherd 'near the Pharos Painter'.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 316, no. B338)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0805) (Phase 1)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 95, pl. III, no. 2)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
